body:
> It is not clear to me what the default value of parse_dates is.

The default values of API docs are shown in the function signature. See [here](http://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/dev/generated/pandas.io.html.read_html.html#pandas.io.html.read_html).

> Alson on read_html is listed as "bool" whereas on read_csv as "boolean, list of ints or names, list of lists, or dict".

I'll fix this and refer the user to the `read_csv` docs.

> I am not sure what setting parse_dates=False does.

What do you think it does? It simply won't try to parse dates/times and will leave them as strings in the result.

Anyway to make that into a link to read_csv in the function signature?
 That'd be nice, though maybe not possible?
Sure ... i think you can refer to other API docs in docstrings

@cpcloud re: "parse_dates=False", I don't understand what is going on here then (see column 2 for example):

that's because `infer_types=True`, and the main reason `infer_types` will have no effect in 0.14. As you can see they conflict with each other because `parse_dates=False` is overridden by `infer_types=True` which performs a hard conversion of dates ... what do you get when you pass `parse_dates=False` and `infer_types=False`?

@cpcloud It might be worth adding a note to the docs about the interaction of these two parameters.
@cancan101 BTW thanks for being so vocal about your `read_html` experience! Always appreciate user feedback!
